Quick Facts

EXIT   X

COMPLIANCE AND ENFORCEMENT MEASURES

Page

Table of Contents

 

 

Click the buttons below for more information

 

 

The court may order an offender to make a WHS undertaking. Legal proceedings will then be adjourned for up to two years, and the offender will be released on the condition that he or she follows the specified conditions in the undertaking.

 

A court-ordered WHS undertaking states the offender must:

 

•

comply with any conditions imposed by the court

•

not commit any offence against the WHS Act during the adjournment

•

appear before the court if called to do so during the period of the adjournment

 

 

If a court finds a person guilty of a WHS offence, the court may issue an injunction ordering the person to stop breaching the Act.

 

 

The court may make an order requiring the offender to undertake a specific project for the general improvement of work health and safety in their workplace within a time period specified in the order.
